item.title: 34 Games To Play If You Love Devil May Cry
item.description:
The first Devil May Cry game was launched in 2001 on the PlayStation 2. What initially began as an early concept for Resident Evil 4 became the standard for a new sub-genre of hack-and-slash action-adventure games. Despite being viewed as an action game sub-genre, the Devil May Cry series harked back to classic beat-em-ups like Golden Axe, Double Dragon, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Arcade.

The primary difference is that games like Devil May Cry are usually single-player affairs giving their players a sense of power. Other studios followed suit with games that used the same power fantasy action-hero concept of their own. This opened the door for many modern-day classics that are still going or equally acclaimed as the Devil May Cry series and solid recommendations for fans looking for something similar.

Updated November 26, 2024, by Hamza Haq: Unlike in other forms of media, seeing elements from one game being copied into another game with a different twist is not considered a bad thing in the gaming industry but as a sign of respect. Entire genres in gaming are named after games that inspired others to follow and try to replicate the same feeling in their titles. Soulslikes and Metroidvanias are perfect examples. Games like Devil May Cry are a rare commodity, however. Despite the game's widespread appeal and cult-classic status, the modern gaming market is not kind to hack-and-slash games that follow the DMC formula. Still, fans of the series have indies and old classics to fall back on when the urge to play a game like DMC compels them.

34 Hades

Fast-Paced Action That Uses A Unique Isometric Perspective

Hades 2 will take some time to get out of its Early Access phase if its predecessor is anything to go by. Supergiant Games' magnum opus hit the ground running and quickly became everyone's favorite action game in 2020, with the perfect harmony between narrative and gameplay helping Hades stand out as one of the best roguelite games ever made.

The frenetic action is pretty similar to Devil May Cry if Dante's adventures were played out from an isometric viewpoint. Such is the excellence of Hades that some fans can only wonder how a Devil May Cry game would play if it implemented roguelite mechanics to make progression more satisfying.

33 Persona 5 Strikers

Combines The Jazzy Vibe Of Persona 5 With Musou Gameplay For A Fun Real-Time Action Twist

The success of Persona 5 encouraged Atlus to go to town and develop a wealth of spinoffs for their hit title. One such game that fans were particularly excited about was Persona 5 Strikers , which served as a spin-off/sequel to the widely beloved Persona 5 .

The game's road trip setting was pretty inspired, even if the attempt to mimic the original game's infiltrations felt rather forced. Still, using a wealth of skills to exploit an enemy's weakness and unleash the patented All-Out Attack makes for a blast every single time. The real-time combat adds some chaotic energy to the game that is perfectly in line with players who want more games like Devil May Cry .

32 Dynasty Warriors 9

The Latest Game In The Long-Running Action Series

Musou games have a niche in gaming that most fans love. Perhaps this is why Dynasty Warriors 9 has its fair share of fans despite some major faults that critics weren't huge fans of at launch.

The game attempts to revitalize the series' formula with mixed results. However, the core action combat continues to be the most cathartic aspect of the series, and there's nothing more satisfying than barreling through waves of opponents with some well-placed attacks.

31 Hyrule Warriors: Age Of Calamity

Combat On An Epic Scale As Players Participate In The War That Destroyed Hyrule Itself

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild was a major step in the right direction for the Zelda series. It revitalized the genre, letting a new swath of players experience the magic of this series and play through one of the greatest open-world games of all time.

It's easy to see why Nintendo jumped at the opportunity to develop a spin-off for this title. Hyrule Warriors: Age of Calamity focuses on an alternate timeline when Link and the other champions had to face off against the villains that arose during Ganon's attempt to destroy Hyrule. It's a Musou title, so it won't be for everyone, but it's also one of the best examples of the genre in recent memory, and further builds on the story in Breath of the Wild.

30 Darksiders 2

The Peak Of An Underrated Series With Great Exploration And Hack-And-Slash Combat

It's a shame that the Darksiders franchise has fallen off the map after the third entry failed to turn heads. Sacrificing a lot of what made the series and becoming just another mediocre Soulslike felt like a slap in the face of fans who loved this series and what it had achieved, especially considering the loyal fan following Darksiders 2 has.

Controlling one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, Death, and aiding him in his quest to save his brother makes for a great and epic adventure. Darksiders 2 is an underrated gem for a reason, and fans of Devil May Cry should definitely check out its fun combat and unique puzzles.

29 Atlas Fallen

A Game Focused On Exploration And Action-Packed Combat

Combining elements of Journey and Devil May Cry, Atlas Fallen is one of the most unique titles on this list. While it borrows from other games in the action genre, it does enough to set itself apart and feature a world that action fans will love to explore and immerse themselves in.

It doesn't always come together flawlessly, and some bugs will irritate some players, but the combat is an excellent homage to the Devil May Cry formula. Navigating the sands is reminiscent of Journey as the player's created character surfs the sand to explore, and there is a surprising amount of depth to its upgrade system.

28 Final Fantasy 16

A Final Fantasy Game Developed With A Prominent Devil May Cry Veteran In A Major Design Role

2023 was a staple year for RPG fans, and Final Fantasy 16 was among the biggest. Despite sticking to the Final Fantasy formula with its exploration and epic battles, the combat is pure Devil May Cry -style action with set pieces and an excellent story.

The pacing takes a hit when the world map gets littered with side quests that amount to little more than traveling to a location, fighting something, and fetching it back to the quest-giver. Even so, it's a superb action game with spectacular boss fights that incorporate the summons from Final Fantasy lore into something new and original.

27 Warhammer 40K: Space Marine

Brutal Melee Combat That Is Perfect For Devil May Cry Fans

Warhammer 40K: Space Marine looks more like a Gears of War clone. While it shares elements with the third-person shooter, it features brutal melee-based combat that fans of Devil May Cry will enjoy. The flow of action is weightier and less fluid, but the sense of scale and violence is on another level.

Despite being a PS3 and Xbox 360 title, Space Marine holds up spectacularly against many modern titles and is just as cinematic now. Warhammer 40: Space Marine 2 is set to launch on current-generation systems.

26 God Of War Greek Mythology Saga

An Old-School Action-Packed Trilogy With Brutal Combat

Even though the Kratos saga moved into Norse mythology, fans of the hack-and-slash action genre should also check out the original God of War games with the backdrop of Greek mythology. Kratos is less likable in these games, but the power fantasy is arguably better than in the recent titles.

The battle system is reminiscent of the older Devil May Cry games, and the boss battles are unmatched in scale. Kratos is taking down Titans that make him look like an insect by comparison. He also fights and destroys regular monsters like the Gorgon, Cyclops, and Minotaurs in cinematic fashion.

25 Gungrave G.O.R.E.

A Tough, Fresh Take On DMC's Formula

Launched in late 2022, Gungrave is an action game similar to the Devil May Cry series. It was criticized early on for having unfair difficulty spikes, but Dante fans who relished the challenge of the Hell and Hell modes will adjust quickly.

Gungrave features stylized supernatural combat where the protagonist will put his enemies down in style. There is a fast-paced industrial metal-style soundtrack, and players are awarded Art points like style points in Devil May Cry for taking down enemies with executions and other skills.

24 Evil West

Fun, Nostalgic Action Combat In A Unique Fantasy-Western Setting

Another action shooter launched at the end of 2022 was Evil West , a pulp action shooter that puts players in the shoes of a vampire hunter in the Wild West. The over-the-shoulder camera and animations are reminiscent of the recent God of War games. Yet the supernatural element and visual style will make it DMC-like in nature.

The core gameplay of Evil West and the way the players can play a style that suits them once they unlock perks make for an accessible and fun experience. The combat is brutal, and there is even an online co-op mode where players can take down vampires together.

23 The Nier Series

Great Stories, Imaginative Combat, And A Focus On Skill-Based Gameplay

Fans looking for games with deep stories and action RPG mechanics should check out the Nier series. Nier: Replicant and Nier Automata are two of the deepest games available, but the action is accessible, fun, and fast. Combat-wise, Nier: Automata is the better game, thanks to being developed by PlatinumGames.

Stylistically, Nier: Automata has similarities to their other titles, like Bayonetta and Astral Chain . However, the improved gameplay mechanics and speed of Nier Replicant - a remake of the original Nier - will be appreciated by fans of Devil May Cry .

22 Scarlet Nexus

A Stylistic Action-JRPG With A Focus On Melee And Telekinetic Combat

Developed by a team that created mainline entries in the Tales and God Eater series, Scarlet Nexus is an anime-style action RPG with a stunning combat system as fast and enjoyable as Devil May Cry. Furthermore, the characters use psychokinetic powers to throw objects at enemies and combine spectacular special attacks.

The combat is fast-paced but strategic and challenging, especially the boss fights. The Devil May Cry games are anime-like in their execution, but Scarlet Nexus is a stunning visual experience that plays like an interactive anime and holds an excellent story.

21 Darksiders

A Post-Apocalyptic Open-World RPG With Great Third-Person Combat

The Darksiders trilogy as a whole takes heavy inspiration from DMC, and nowhere is it more apparent than in the first entry in the franchise. Darksiders is a third-person hack-and-slash game where players take control of one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse from legend, War, as he traverses a post-apocalyptic Earth searching for the entity who was responsible for starting the war that destroyed the planet.

Combat is the main focus of Darksiders , though environmental puzzles are a huge factor as well. It shares a lot of similarities with the original God of War games and Devil May Cry , like new weapon types that completely change the way fights play out, demonic themes with deep lore, and combo meters that build up over time.

20 Soulstice

A Fluid Hack-And-Slash Game In An Apocalyptic Setting

Launched in 2022, Soulstice is an action hack-and-slash game heavily inspired by the Devil May Cry series. It features an apocalyptic setting that is grim but full of stunning visual set pieces that fans of the genre will instantly click with.

While not quite as polished as the games that inspired it, Soulstice is a fluid action game with strategic mechanics that are easy to pick up and challenging to master. The tactical element borrows from Ikaruga with color-coordinated attacks that ramp up the challenge, but eventually, the fighting system will click like second nature.

19 X-Men Origins: Wolverine

A Surprisingly Great Movie Tie-In With Brutal, Visceral Combat

  • Platform(s): PlayStation 3, PlayStation 2, PSP, Xbox 360, Nintendo DS, Nintendo Wii, PC
  • Release Date: May 1, 2009
  • Developer(s): Raven Software, Amaze Entertainment

X-Men Origins: Wolverine is a movie tie-in game that many fans considered more entertaining than its source material. It used the God of War series as inspiration, and it was the perfect fit. Wolverine is violent, deadly, and the anti-hero he's supposed to be.

The game is far more violent and bloody than the movie and features a combat system inspired by the God of War series. The combat lacks the complexities of Devil May Cry, but fans of the genre will enjoy the brutal mechanics and will feel right at home with Wolverine .

18 Conan

A Fun Conan The Barbarian Game With Tough Yet Enjoyable Combat

Conan was launched in 2007 on the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360. It was an overlooked title because of its similarities to the God of War series. While it may be fair to call Conan a God of War clone, its counter-attack system, equipment mechanics, and weapon variety were far superior, and the emphasis on counters played a more significant part. It must be said that Conan lacks the epic triple-A movie-like feel of God of War, which is a shame.

Furthermore, Conan the Barbarian was the ultimate power fantasy in fiction long before God of War and Devil May Cry. Additionally , Conan features artwork inspired by the original works of Frank Frazetta, an award-winning soundtrack, and stellar voice work from Ron Perlman and Claudia Black in the lead roles. It is still the best Conan the Barbarian game, where players get to play as the titular character.

17 Transformers: Devastation

A Fun Transformers Game By PlatinumGames, The Masters Of Hack-And-Slash Combat

Developed by PlatinumGames and released in 2015, Transformers: Devastation was an action title that combines hack-slash gameplay and shooting mechanics similar to Devil May Cry and other Platinum titles. Players take on the roles of Autobot heroes Optimus Prime, Bumblebee, Grimlock, Sideswipe, and Wheeljack in a stunning throwback to the classic 1980s cartoons.

Like the Devil May Cry series, Transformers: Devastation incorporates fast action, gameplay variety, timing, and memorable boss battles. Players can also upgrade their move sets with TECH enhancements that increase the statistics of the Autobots as the game progresses.

16 Ghost Of Tsushima

Sucker Punch's Excellent Action-Packed Open-World Game Set During The Mongol Invasion Of Japan

Released in 2020, Ghost of Tsushima was one of the biggest hits of the year and is considered by fans as one of the best PlayStation 4 exclusives. While the gameplay mechanics and open-world nature are fundamentally different from the Devil May Cry series, Tsushima's timing-based combat is something that fans of the Capcom series will appreciate.

Every fight in the game is thrilling, and there are multiple ways to take down enemies, whether in a duel or by using ninja-like stealth tactics. The power fantasy takes precedence in the later stages of the narrative when the protagonist Jin gains his Ghost skills, where he fights like an unstoppable supernatural being.

15 Ryse: Son Of Rome

A Hack-And-Slash Launch Title For The Xbox One

Released as a launch title for the Xbox One, Ryse: Son of Rome is a historical action game with a fighting system that combines elements of Devil May Cry, God of War, and Batman: Arkham games. The production values are still fantastic, the voice acting is top-notch, and the facial animations remain some of the best today.

While the game was criticized for lacking variety outside of fighting, Ryse' s combat-heavy mechanics are perfect for Devil May Cry fans who enjoy taking down multiple enemies with cinematic flair. While the fighting system has more in common with the Arkham series than Devil May Cry , there's enough action in Ryse to please even the most jaded of action fans.

item.title: Pokemon GO: Beyond Wild Area Expert Timed Research Rewards
item.description:
The fun of Pokemon GO 's Wild Area Global event has been extended with the introduction of the Beyond Wild Area Expert Timed Research. Completing the tasks will get you some highly desirable items such as Rare Candies and Lucky Eggs to help improve your team and gain more experience towards level 50. The best bit about all of this is is that it refreshes every day during this week if you met the conditions to unlock it.

This extra Timed Research is only available to those who completed the An Accomplished Trainer Special Research during either of the Pokemon GO 's Wild Area events and have received either the Electric Expert or Poison Expert badge. Depending on their choice during the Wild Area Global event, you'll find the following Beyond Wild Area Timed Research, as well as all of the rewards you get for completing the research and a top tip in order for you to finish these tasks quickly.

Pokemon GO: Beyond Wild Area Expert Timed Research

The Pokemon GO Beyond Wild Area Expert Timed Research will appear every day in the morning at 6 AM and last until 8 PM local time. This is repeatable every day from November 25, with the last of these Timed Research appearing on November 29. Make sure you complete the previous day's research before it expires so that you can get all the rewards. It shouldn't take more than a couple of minutes of play each day.

As for how to complete it quickly, you can take advantage of the GO Rocket balloons to complete two of these tasks at once, then power up a single Pokemon to finish the challenges within minutes. They will include Water or Flying types if you chose the Electric route in the An Accomplished Trainer Special Research, and Grass or Fairy types if you chose the Poison route instead.

Pokemon GO: Beyond Wild Area Electric Expert Timed Research

Timed Research

Reward

Power up one Electric-type Pokemon

Ultra Ball x15

Defeat three Water and/or Flying-type Pokemon

Max Potion x3

Defeat one Team Go Rocket member

Max Revive x3

Rewards for completion

  • Rare Candy x3
  • Stardust x1000
  • Lucky Egg x1

Pokemon GO: Beyond Wild Area Poison Expert Timed Research

Timed Research

Reward

Power up one Poison-type Pokemon

Ultra Ball x15

Defeat three Grass and/or Fairy-type Pokemon

Max Potion x3

Defeat one Team Go Rocket member

Max Revive x3

Rewards for completion

  • Rare Candy x3
  • Stardust x1000
  • Lucky Egg x1

item.title: Final Fantasy: 8 Most Beautiful Locations In The Games
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Altissia: Beautiful but tricky-to-navigate city with a lucrative hotel for players.
  • Red Moon: Fantastical moon setting in FF4 finale with serene beauty.
  • Bhujerba: A floating settlement in FF12 offering stunning visuals and exploration joys.

Final Fantasy is a series that has constantly pushed the boundaries of gaming, letting players enjoy everything from beautiful graphics to cutting-edge combat that always strives to be ahead of the curve. The focus on impressive visuals makes it clear why some locations in the Final Fantasy can be a joy to witness.

Players will fondly remember some of the most beautiful areas in the games that are a treat for the eyes. Stellar art direction, amazing graphics, and excellent presentation ensure that these iconic locations will have a meaningful impact on players who take in all the splendor and magnificence of these locations.

1 Altissia

A Breathtaking City That Can Be A Bit Of A Pain To Navigate

Altissia may be one of the most irritating cities to explore in gaming history, but there's no denying that this location oozes charm and beauty from the very moment players lay their eyes on this location for the first time. The parallels to Venice are clear as day and make this city easy on the eyes.

Altissia also boasts one of the most lucrative resting spots in the game, with the Leville Hotel providing a massive boost to the player's stocked experience if they splurge for a luxurious room. It's a city that fans won't mind coming back to over and over again once they figure out the best way to avoid some narrow pathways and alleys that can be annoying to navigate.

2 Red Moon

Heading To The Moon Makes For A Breathtaking Moment

For a game with high fantasy elements that are clear as day, the finale of Final Fantasy 4 whisks players away to a location that they could've never imagined. The idea of exploring the moon and preventing Zemus' plans from becoming a reality is a great way to keep fans entertained for the finale.

Despite its simple appearance, there's something about the melancholic isolation of the moon that makes it a unique overworld for players to explore. The pixel art helps convey the serene beauty of this place, which will entice players to explore the surface of the Red Moon and uncover its secrets.

3 Bhujerba

This Floating Settlement Is A Joy To See For The First Time

Floating cities are always a joy to look at if the architecture and visual design are on point, which is why Bhujerba is such a great location to explore in Final Fantasy 12 . This massive city is a joy to explore as players uncover all the content they can get their hands on here.

Spreading rumors, completing hunts, and doing errands feel better than ever with the backdrop of this sky city that is full of stunning backdrops. Players will have a great time going through Final Fantasy 12 , with this location being one of the many highlights of their epic adventure.

4 Lestallum

An Iconic City Full Of Memorable Landmarks

If there's one thing Final Fantasy 15 nails, it's the look and feel of its cities. After a lengthy road trip, the player's first steps in Lestallum will feel like a much-needed respite from all the running and fighting. This city is a joy to behold, with players engaging in several side quests, exploring the market, and furthering the main plot.

Lestallum is a great city to come back to after a long, hard day of adventuring. The Leville Hotel here provides a great experience boost that fans will love to make the most of to ensure that their level-ups are as efficient as possible.

5 Macalania Woods

An Ethereal Location That Serves As The Backdrop For One Of The Game's Most Emotional Moments

One of the most beautiful locations in Final Fantasy , the earthy blue hues of Macalania Woods make it a beautiful location for players to look at the first time they enter this area. It's an important area in both the first game and its sequel, with one of the most iconic moments in Final Fantasy 10 taking place here.

Most fans will agree that the moment when Tidus and Yuna finally cement their romance with a kiss was even more impactful since this event occurred in the Macalania Woods. The beautiful and romantic backdrop is the perfect place for the two protagonists to share this intimate moment.

6 Fisherman's Horizon

A Beautiful Seaside Town Accompanied By Amazing Music

Some of the best locations in Final Fantasy are the ones that let players stop and smell the roses after numerous battles and boss fights. Fisherman's Horizon does precisely that, with the amazing OST accompanying this town being one of the best tracks in Final Fantasy 8 .

The scenic views and an enrapturing view of the sea ensure that players will have a great time maximizing the time spent in Fisherman's Horizon. Final Fantasy 8 is a game known for its amazing visuals, and Fisherman's Horizon is one of the many areas that wowed players back in the day.

7 Lindblum

An Amazing City That Plays A Central Role In The Story

The magical high fantasy setting of Final Fantasy 9 injects a lot of charm to its locations, and nowhere is this more apparent than the city of Lindblum. This massive area is bursting with color as players explore its nooks and crannies to uncover every secret they can get their hands on.

The Festival of the Hunt is one of the most iconic and beloved set pieces in this game that takes place entirely in Lindblum. Using Air Cabs to head from one district to another as players find numerous distractions to keep them busy adds to the beauty of this city.

8 Aerith's House

A Beautiful Place Surrounded By Flowers, Making It A Beautiful Sight In The Otherwise Bleak Setting Of Midgar

The city of Midgar is coated in monochromatic hues with a few neon colors present here and there. It hammers in just how dystopian this city is, which is why seeing Aerith's house in the Sector 5 slums is such a breath of fresh air.

Her home is covered in flowers, making it a beautiful place to behold as Cloud and Aerith deepen their bond after their fateful meeting. No matter how drab the colors in Midgar can be, the sight of this faithfully updated location in the Remake makes these sights more than bearable.

item.title: The 30 Best Looking Games On High-End PCs
item.description:
The release of the PS5 and Xbox One Series X|S has once again brought the conversation of consoles vs. PCs back to the forefront of the gaming industry. The pros and cons can be debated for hours, but there's one indisputable benefit of playing on PC. If someone has the funds to afford the high-end hardware, PC gaming provides the best visual and graphical performance around. Because the majority of gamers don't own high-end PCs, many developers aren't willing to spend too much time optimizing their games.

After all, the majority of players won't get the chance to see them performing at the top level. That's not to say that there's a shortage of games that will test the limits of even the best hardware though. Numerous games compensate players for the eye-watering investments that top builds require. It's worth pointing out that the best-looking PC games around are judged on the developer's intended product; adding mods into the equation would turn this into an entirely different list.

Updated November 26, 2024, by Hamza Haq: Developers never make games exclusively for the highest end of the PC market because only a small minority of gamers have maxed out PC rigs with 4090 GPUs and 14th generation i9s to fall back on. Most games are made with the lowest common denominator in mind, aiming to run smoothly on low and mid-tier PCs instead. But with the increased popularity of ray tracing, frame generation, and new technologies that add another graphical dimension to PC games, even high-end PC owners may find themselves having trouble running everything on Ultra settings without any upscalers.

1 Ghost Of Tsushima

Incredible Visual Design Helps Tsushima Island Look Wonderful

Ghost of Tsushima is one of the prettiest open-world games ever made, and it's easy to see why its launch on PC was celebrated by the masses. Players loved the idea of rendering the beautiful visuals of Tsushima Island on their high-end PCs, and the stable nature of the game's launch meant that players didn't have to struggle while running it.

The combination of technical excellence and a stunning art style ensures that Jin's adventures are easy on the eyes. Sony's exclusives are known for boasting state-of-the-art visuals, and Ghost of Tsushima doesn't disappoint in this regard.

2 Final Fantasy 7 Remake

Blows Away Everyone's Mental Image Of What The Original Game Looked Like In Their Heads

Final Fantasy 7 Remake is a game that everyone was anticipating with bated breath. While the game's visuals were a cut above the rest, there was some poor texture work that prevented players from enjoying the full potential of this title's graphics. Thankfully, all of these complaints were squashed when players got their hands on the PC port.

Without any of the restrictions that hampered the PS4, Final Fantasy 7 Remake looked like a gem on the PC. While a PS5 port eventually fixed most of the complaints players had when it came to the console, Remake is still one of the best-looking PC games that players will love staring at as long as they have the hardware to support the visuals.

3 Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered

New York Looks Gorgeous As Players Swing Through The City In Style

Most people felt that a remaster of Marvel's Spider-Man was completely unnecessary, given how good the game looked already. However, Sony was adamant about pushing out a release that further enhanced the game's visuals, and fans couldn't deny that Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered looked like an absolute treat when it came out. The change to Peter Parker's face was the only downer in a game that looked stellar otherwise.

With its release on computers, Marvel's Spider-Man quickly became one of the best-looking PC games that players could get their hands on. The visuals look spellbinding as players swing to their heart's content, reaching extremely high speeds as they make their way through the streets of New York and complete the many missions that come their way.

4 Avatar: Frontiers Of Pandora

Pandora Looks Breathtaking When Players Step Into The World For The First Time

There's no denying that Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora had some problems that stopped it from becoming a worthy movie tie-in that most people wanted it to be. The dated world design, an incessant focus on gathering, and a poor main story all stopped this game from reaching the glorious heights it could've achieved.

However, one aspect of the game that has been universally lauded is its visuals, with the various biomes of Pandora looking downright breathtaking. The visual spectacle of this game will bombard players time and time again as they explore more and more of this gorgeous world. On a PC with the settings cranked up to the max, the sheer quality of the graphics is more than enough to make up for the game's drawbacks.

5 Horizon: Forbidden West

A Beautiful Game Done Justice To By A PC Port That Lets It Shine

Sony hasn't enjoyed the best success with its PC ports, with most games launching in a less-than-ideal state that always takes away something from what should otherwise have been an immaculate experience for players who were salivating to play these PlayStation exclusives for the longest time. So, when Horizon Forbidden West dropped, players were more than pleased to see the amazing quality of this PC port and how it elevated the quality of this game to new heights.

The game's visual quality was a step above in every way, making it one of the finest games players can check out on the PC in no time. The massive open world can be enjoyed in all its splendor, which more than makes this port worth the price of admission.

6 Hogwarts Legacy

Gazing Upon Hogwarts And The Scottish Highlands' Beauty In The Late 1800s Is Amazing

The hype for Hogwarts Legacy was through the roof before it came out, with most people loving the idea of finally getting their hands on a game that feels like an original adventure through the halls of Hogwarts instead of a rehash of the movies. Despite some flaws revolving around the story, voice performances, and the immersion of the player as a student, Hogwarts Legacy was an incredible celebration of Harry Potter 's legacy in every way.

The world of Hogwarts and the Scottish Highlands is a blast to explore, and it's easy to see why people couldn't get enough of this game when it launched. The PC port was shambolic but has been fixed with numerous patches, making it worth checking out if players want to push the graphical fidelity of this game to the max.

7 Cyberpunk 2077

Overdrive Mode Will Take Anyone's Breath Away

Ray-tracing is the biggest craze to hit PC gaming, and it's easy to see why players are going crazy about this new revolution in graphics. Lighting plays a huge role in deciding how a game looks, and ray-tracing aims to overhaul this aspect of a game's graphics to make things look more realistic than ever before.

Ray-tracing made Cyberpunk 2077 look gorgeous once the game was stable enough. For players who have the hardware, Overdrive mode can be triggered to unlock a version of ray-tracing so complex that it's downright impossible to use this mode without DLSS, even on high-end graphic cards!

8 Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales

Ray-Tracing Makes New York Look Unbelievably Good

The release of PlayStation exclusives on PC has been a boon for people who game on the latter. As long as games are released with proper optimizations, the PC can render PS exclusives at higher resolutions and frame rates, making these titles look more impressive than they already are.

Miles Morales is a great standalone expansion to Marvel's Spider-Man , with the powers of this hero being a joy to mess around with. Fans can't wait to get their hands on Marvel's Spider-Man 2 and play as both Spider-Men in one game. With the release of the sequel coming sooner rather than later, there's no better time to check out the first few games in the series if players want to get up to date with the story of Insomniac's amazing Spider-Man adventure.

9 A Plague Tale: Requiem

A Sequel That's Bigger, Better, And More Gorgeous Than Ever Before

A Plague Tale: Requiem benefited from the immense success of its predecessor. The areas in this game are bigger than ever before, with the graphical prowess of this title being a sight to behold. Rats may be disgusting, but seeing so many tiny creatures being rendered at the same time on powerful PCs makes for a pretty memorable image.

A Plague Tale: Requiem may lack the focused approach of its predecessor, but it more than makes up for it with its broader and more impressive scope. The story also reaches an emotional conclusion that fans will love, especially if they are invested in the struggles of Amicia and Hugo.

10 Uncharted 4: A Thief's End

The Best-Looking Uncharted Game That Still Holds Up

Uncharted 4: A Thief's End serves as the final chapter in Nathan Drake's story. It's also a massive improvement in every way, with everything from the graphics to the individual levels being massive. The game was a technical masterpiece at the time of launch and still looks drop-dead gorgeous to this day.

Players who are lucky enough to crank the settings of this title to the max will find their jaw falling on the floor as they gaze upon some of the more beautiful areas in the game. The release of this game on PC was very much necessary for players who wanted to enjoy the visual fidelity of this title at its highest level without any console hardware limitations standing in the way.

11 God Of War

A Beautiful-Looking Chapter In This Illustrious Series

God of War is another great PlayStation exclusive that made its way to PC after a lengthy hiatus. Kratos' return to the mainstream was a massive success and looks amazing at the highest settings and 60 FPS. Given the action-heavy focus of God of War , it's easy to see why a higher framerate would be perfect for this title.

Fans can't wait to see God of War Ragnarok on the PC, with Kratos' final chapter in Norse mythology having the potential to look amazing on a high-end PC. These players have been waiting for a long time, and fans who either own a PC or prioritize graphics were more than elated when this port was finally announced after a lengthy wait.

12 Dead Space Remake

A Stunning Visual Upgrade To A Horror Classic

The Dead Space Remake was hotly anticipated, with the game being absolutely timeless and truly gorgeous to behold to this day. Many fans were worried that a remake would lose a lot of what made this title amazing, but that isn't necessarily the case. The changes to Isaac's character and certain interactions may have more of a mixed reception, but the game itself is solid and looks gorgeous.

It helps that certain areas have been expanded upon quite a bit to give returning fans something to look forward to. The Dead Space remake more than justifies its existence, making it clear why so many people are looking forward to the future of the Dead Space series.

13 Microsoft Flight Simulator

Continues The Trend Of The Series By Boasting State-Of-The-Art Graphics

Microsoft Flight Simulator was released in August 2020, and let players explore the world at a time when much of the world was in lockdown. Asobo Studio's game features an incredible rendition of Earth thanks to data from Bing Maps, letting players fly over some of the most iconic locations across the globe.

The game's rendition of Earth is the main selling point for many players. For others though, the flight controls are also a treat for anyone wanting an authentic, immersive experience.

14 Star Wars: Squadrons

Dogfighting In Star Wars Has Never Looked This Good

From one flying game to another, Star Wars: Squadrons ditches Microsoft Flight Simulator 's realism for the fantasy sci-fi battles from the Star Wars universe. Where Flight Simulator provides a true-to-life look at Earth, Squadrons throws players in enormous space battles with countless ships engaging in combat.

Rather than giving players a third-person perspective of their ship, the game puts them front and center in the cockpit. This helps to provide an engrossing experience. The incredible warfare visuals combined with the immersive sound design make players feel like they're in the midst of battle.

15 Hitman 3

The Third Game In The Hitman Reboot That Looks And Feels Exceptional

A game centered around being a hitman may not seem like a natural source of stunning locations. However, Agent 47 is lucky enough to travel to numerous beautiful areas throughout 2021's Hitman 3 .

From the game's starting location of Dubai to a quintessential British manor to a vibrant nightclub in Berlin, these locations will put the capabilities of even high-end PCs to the test. Hitman 3 treats players to an incredible range of places to see while conducting their deadly missions throughout the eight-hour story.

16 F1 23

Codemasters' Renown For Featuring Games With Amazing Visuals Continues With This Flawed Entry

This entry in the F1 gaming franchise is another great entry in a series that continues to push the boundaries of racing sims to their very limit. While there are some issues that players can point out in this title, there's no denying that it's still one of the best motorsport games that fans can get their hands on.

The game's many great modes can provide hundreds of hours of entertainment for die-hard Formula 1 fans. However, F1 23 wasn't just beloved by fans of the sport in real life. The game's incredible attention to detail brought a whole new audience to the motorsport. Many gamers were instantly encapsulated by the game's immersive look and feel.

17 Dirt 5

Beautiful Visuals And Impressive Effects Make This Racing Game's Visuals Stand Out

Dirt 5 was developed by Codemasters, the same studio that developed the F1 series . This game, however, takes players to the other side of the racing spectrum. Instead of crisp, meticulously designed tracks in the heart of some of the world's most stunning cities, Dirt 5 takes players to grimy tracks that will put the player's car handling skills to the test.

There's no denying that the game looks fantastic on top-of-the-range rigs and is thus well worth checking out for PC players who enjoy a good racing game.

18 Star Wars Battlefront 2

Lauded For Its Visuals, Even During Its Stunted And Infamous Launch

To say that EA had a tough time with the marketing of Star Wars Battlefront 2 would be an understatement, as the implementation of microtransactions understandably soured many players on the Star Wars title.

As much as some players would like to ignore the game, it's hard to deny that EA provided players with an incredible, immersive visual experience that truly made players feel like they were in the movies.

19 Just Cause 4

The Best-Looking Game In The Series

For developers, there are plenty of great things about creating an open-world setting in a fictional location. One of the greatest is that there's no limit to how ambitious and extraordinary the game world can look.

Just Cause 4 takes place in a fictional South American country named Solís. The stunning landscapes aren't Solís' only impressive feature though. The country suffers from frequent thunderstorms and tornados that will test not just the player's capability to survive, but the capabilities of their PC's hardware too.

20 Assassin’s Creed Valhalla

A Massive Open World That Looks Amazing With All The Settings Cranked To The Max

When Assassin's Creed Origins took Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed series in a more RPG-centric direction, it wasn't just the gameplay that changed, but the franchise's already impressive visuals took a sharp increase in quality too. The game's visuals have been improving since, and the latest iteration, Valhalla has the best aesthetics yet.

Valhalla takes players to Norway for the first time in the series, as well as taking them back to England; this time in the 9th century. For those with the processing power needed to crank the settings, it's one of the best-looking games on PC , not to mention one of the best Assassin's Creed games in years.

item.title: Call of Duty Zombies: 8 Easiest Maps
item.description:
Call of Duty Zombies has been a stellar experience for over a decade, and with Black Ops 6 bringing forth even more zombie content, some new players might want to know what some of the easiest COD Zombies maps are from past iterations so that they can jump in and better understand the round-based gameplay loop and reach the highest rounds they can muster.

While there have been some truly tough maps in the COD Zombies franchise, there are some maps that are way easier than the rest, and they allow players to have a great deal of fun without having an abundance of fear of getting trapped or killed in the early rounds.

8 Buried

Fun and Overpowered Weapons for an Easy Ride to Round 100

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops 2

Buried was once the final map for the Victis crew in Black Ops 2 , and as such, they were provided with a celebration. Buried is a big blow-out, a grand adventure that focuses on fun and overpowered mechanics rather than story and buildables. Buried excels in weapon variety with the Paralyzer allowing for free movement and the ability to slow zombies, and the Time Bomb permitting players to rewind rounds in case of death.

Buried also provides plenty of ways to get all the Perks with the ghost girls in the mansion that barely do damage but steal points with every hit. When killing them all, a free Perk Power-Up is provided. So many mechanics to obtain basically everything makes for an easy and fun ride, and the Subsurface Resonator paired with the Turbine at the Jugger-Nog spot allows players to stand still and reach well over round 100.

7 Liberty Falls

A Spacious West Virginia Town With All Perks and Powerful Weapons

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops 6

One of the easiest COD Zombies maps comes from the most recent iteration of the mode with Liberty Falls. This map is definitely easy, not only in terms of its speed-running easter egg main quest but also in terms of map layout. Liberty Falls is easy to navigate, and there are no steps required to unlock Perks or Pack-a-Punch, since the power is already on and players just need to spend Essence on the doors to open it all up.

The fact that players can buy all Perks, obtain the OP Wonder Weapons through free quests, and get Tier-3 Pack-a-Punch weapons makes for an easy camo grind, especially when the spaces available are very open with desolate streets with abandoned cars that can be vaulted over. The only true difficulty in Liberty Falls comes from the Mangler spam that occurs after around Round 30, and even then a Scorestreak can easily take them out.

6 Der Eisendrache

Simple for Those Who Want to Train, Expansive for Those on a Quest

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops 3

Der Eisendrache is the perfect blend of classic COD Zombies and new COD Zombies . For those who want a more classic experience where they can turn on the power, spin the Mystery Box, grab their Perks and enjoy Pack-a-Punch, then they certainly can, especially with the easy and open spaces that allow for fun hordes of zombies to pile up without risk of being devoured alive.

Yet, there’s a layer of friendly complexity to Der Eisendrache that veterans might enjoy thanks to its main quest and the Wrath of the Ancients bow that takes cues from Mob of the Dead to obtain, and its four distinct upgrades are fun to work on. It’s not an overly complicated map, and it's easily one of the best.

5 Der Riese

Everything a Zombies Map Needs with Areas, Perks, and Upgrades

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: World at War, Call of Duty: Black Ops , Call of Duty: Black Ops 3

The first map to feature Pack-a-Punch is still one of the easiest to date for numerous reasons. Not only does the addition of Pack-a-Punch make for a whopping good time with weapons that will deal more damage, but the map layout itself provides some nice areas for players to navigate and manipulate zombie spawns.

Players who work together can also head up to the catwalk and help each other stand their ground and camp in one spot for round after round with ease. The addition of the Wunderwaffe DG-2 also helps eradicate hordes of undead with a single blast, and Der Riese is a competent enough size that it doesn’t feel overwhelming, but doesn’t feel claustrophobic either.

4 Kino Der Toten

Back to Basics in an Open Theater of the Damned

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops , Call of Duty: Black Ops 3

Kino Der Toten proves the beauty in simplicity, as this starting map for Black Ops takes players to a boxed-in theater with a few rooms where every player can have their own spot to hunker down in and train zombies. Kino der Toten is easy to navigate, and getting lost is practically impossible with how close-knit each room is.

There is some challenge in Kino der Toten with its use of Nova-Six Crawlers, but they are easily avoided in the open areas, like training backstage of the theater or in the courtyard garage area. It’s a fun map that’s a true classic for a reason, and its easy design makes for common high rounds.

3 Firebase Z

Exclusive Wonder Weapon and Expansive Areas Makes Training Even Easier

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War

Firebase Z was the second map to grace Black Ops Cold War , and the difficulty did not increase all that much. Firebase Z has some very open areas where training is a cakewalk, and players can easily just walk in circles around hordes of zombies. There are some minor challenges, like the fright of Mimics and the dreaded Orda rounds, but they are easy enough to take care of with Scorestreaks.

With such open spaces, Firebase Z is made even easier with the map-specific Wonder Weapon: the RAI K-84, which is essentially a Ray Gun Assault Rifle that decimates zombies on high rounds. Black Ops Cold War is very easy when it comes to Zombies content, and Firebase Z is one of the easiest maps out there.

2 Die Maschine

Extremely Open Spaces and the Ability to Purchase All Perks

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War

The first map for Black Ops Cold War promised something new, and it did so by going back to the beginning with a new rendition of Nacht der Untoten. Black Ops Cold War has unique mechanics to previous COD titles, and the use of a three-tier Pack-a-Punch, weapon rarity upgrades, loadouts, vaulting, and armor stations made the game all the easier. Mechanics aside, the map itself was pretty easy.

Die Maschine is extremely open, and many areas outside of Nacht der Untoten are easy to train in. Whether it’s the spawn area outside Nacht or the airfield itself, so many spots in Die Maschine benefit from players simply running circles around zombies to easily achieve high rounds.

1 Ascension

Great Places to Train Zombies and Easy Access to Perks

  • Featured in: Call of Duty: Black Ops , Call of Duty: Black Ops 3

As one of the starting maps for Black Ops , Ascension proves how easy certain strategies can be in COD Zombies . Ascension is a nice open map in which players have plenty of spots to which they can train zombies. The central courtyard where PhD Flopper / Widow’s Wine is located is perhaps the easiest training spot in COD Zombies history due to its giant square shape.

On top of easy training spots set about the map, there are no hellhounds to torment players. However, there is the addition of zombie space monkeys that will beat up Perk-a-Cola machines. If successful, players lose the Perk and have to buy it again. It’s not the end of the world, but it can be frustrating, but it still doesn’t take away from how easy this map can be.
